snippet.textDisplay:
You go into great length about why would Scrooge make loans to people he knew couldn't pay. So on the pretense you don't know... There was a whole fucking industry of what is in any meaningful way equal to slavery that was very common in the time period that this book is set. When i was a child and the concept of "indentured servitude" was explained to me by my history teacher they did a good job of making it seem like something people "chose" to participate in. Reality is that in this time period if you fell into a debt you could not pay off, it wasn't just your home and property the debt holder could place a lean against the debtor under which case the debt holder essentially owned the debtor.

Most of the white "settlers" of early America were people who had their debts transferred to wealthy land owners in the colonies. Georgia for one started off as a penal colony for debtors or "indentured servants" who between hereditary debt and "costs of housing" would never be able to work their way out of servitude. This is not to say that slavery, that is, African men women and children seized from their homes, shipped over seas in indescribably bad conditions, and sold as property isn't in all ways worse, but debt slavery was very much a thing. For example in Oliver Twist the orphanage owner makes a very clear and specific effort to sell Oliver... as in literally sell him. This was a thing that use to happen and while it was outlawed in the colonies and then the states, the practice survived in England and other parts of Europe for much longer.

So. Yes. There were reasons that someone might make a loan to someone who could not hope to pay it off. And reasons that people who owed someone like Scrooge money would be very happy in deed to know he was dead.
snippet.textOriginal:
You go into great length about why would Scrooge make loans to people he knew couldn't pay. So on the pretense you don't know... There was a whole fucking industry of what is in any meaningful way equal to slavery that was very common in the time period that this book is set. When i was a child and the concept of "indentured servitude" was explained to me by my history teacher they did a good job of making it seem like something people "chose" to participate in. Reality is that in this time period if you fell into a debt you could not pay off, it wasn't just your home and property the debt holder could place a lean against the debtor under which case the debt holder essentially owned the debtor. 

Most of the white "settlers" of early America were people who had their debts transferred to wealthy land owners in the colonies. Georgia for one started off as a penal colony for debtors or "indentured servants" who between hereditary debt and "costs of housing" would never be able to work their way out of servitude. This is not to say that slavery, that is, African men women and children seized from their homes, shipped over seas in indescribably bad conditions, and sold as property isn't in all ways worse, but debt slavery was very much a thing. For example in Oliver Twist the orphanage owner makes a very clear and specific effort to sell Oliver... as in literally sell him. This was a thing that use to happen and while it was outlawed in the colonies and then the states, the practice survived in England and other parts of Europe for much longer. 

So. Yes. There were reasons that someone might make a loan to someone who could not hope to pay it off. And reasons that people who owed someone like Scrooge money would be very happy in deed to know he was dead.

snippet.textDisplay: Hey Jeremy. The reason Scrooge gets a second chance is explained in one story I read a while back. It's from Marley's point of view. In order for Marley to get a second chance, he has to change Scrooge's heart. This is his task because Scrooge is even more heartless than Marley was, so it is a very difficult task. And Marley is revealed to be the spirits of Christmas in disguise.
snippet.textOriginal: Hey Jeremy. The reason Scrooge gets a second chance is explained in one story I read a while back. It's from Marley's point of view. In order for Marley to get a second chance, he has to change Scrooge's heart. This is his task because Scrooge is even more heartless than Marley was, so it is a very difficult task. And Marley is revealed to be the spirits of Christmas in disguise.

snippet.textDisplay: My guess is that Scrooge never actually seized property in forfeiture from people who defaulted on loans.  Back in the mid 1800's I am sure they probably sent people who couldn't pay debts to Debtors' prison where they toiled away "earning" money that went straight to the pocket of the person they owned.  Kind of like indentured servitude or slavery.
snippet.textOriginal: My guess is that Scrooge never actually seized property in forfeiture from people who defaulted on loans. Kind of like indentured servitude or slavery.

snippet.textDisplay:
"What kind of drugs did they have back then?"
Laudanum. It was called laudanum, and it was a tincture of opium containing approximately 10% powdered opium by weight (the equivalent of 1% morphine).
snippet.textOriginal:
"What kind of drugs did they have back then?"

snippet.textDisplay: Bro, you are really reaching in this, finding the dumbest things to whine about. It's a movie, make believe even more so with puppets. Nothing in this movie has to align with your goofy life. That's what it's there for, escape. I've seen your other reviews and I am a fan but here, you seem to be a Scrooge worse then the one in the movie. Sorry, your petty whining here is just sad. Your just mad cause NO ONE is thinking or caring about YOU when they make their films so you have to blubber like a ho to be noticed. It use to work, now you just sound desperate to stay vital. Hour glass not in your favor. That's why to this day there is NO statue of any critic anywhere. Shocker!

snippet.textDisplay: Timeline: strock of 1am 12/25, spirit of Christmas past shows up. 2am 12/25, spirit of Christmas present shows up. This spirit only lives 24 hours, that's why he has over 1800 brothers. At the stroke of midnight, he dies. At that time, in the spirit realm, 12am 12/26, the spirit of Christmas future shows up.
snippet.textOriginal: Timeline: strock of 1am 12/25, spirit of Christmas past shows up. 2am 12/25, spirit of Christmas present shows up. This spirit only lives 24 hours, that's why he has over 1800 brothers. At the stroke of midnight, he dies. At that time, in the spirit realm, 12am 12/26, the spirit of Christmas future shows up.

snippet.textDisplay: The most obvious cinema sin was missed. Ebenezer Scrooge is so stingy he only has one employee, Bob Cratchit, who he’s refused to give a raise in years. But somehow in this version he’s got several rat bookkeepers. How much is this tightwad paying them? And if they are slaving away in the cold office and putting up with his abuse for free, why?
snippet.textOriginal: The most obvious cinema sin was missed. Ebenezer Scrooge is so stingy he only has one employee, Bob Cratchit, who he’s refused to give a raise in years. But somehow in this version he’s got several rat bookkeepers. How much is this tightwad paying them? And if they are slaving away in the cold office and putting up with his abuse for free, why?

snippet.textDisplay:
(1:15) Well, in The Chronicles of Narnia: The Magician's Nephew, it's clearly shown that Aslan grants intelligence to some individuals of certain species. Maybe it's the same thing in this reality?
(1:33) It could have been an accident.
(2:33 - 2:40) As a mouse owner, I can tell you that mice WILL eat a little cheese in their diets IF it's a dry cheese. out of my 171 total mice, only a small fraction (less than 10) regularly liked it and most of them preferred dry, shredded cheeses. There's too much fat in most cheeses for mice to eat it too much.
(9:12) Eh. That's why there's Boxing Day.
(14:40) 1.) The "gender pay gap" is more of a result of women bitching after the fact instead of learning how to negotiate salaries (and also not knowing the difference of the values of an actor's/actress' name) 2.) If your "money muscle" is your strength, use it. Screw those who bitch. "They just be hatin'."
(14:52) Lagomorph, not rodent. Hey, if you're going to be a nit-picking asshole, then so am I!
snippet.textOriginal:
(1:15) Well, in The Chronicles of Narnia: The Magician's Nephew, it's clearly shown that Aslan grants intelligence to some individuals of certain species.  Maybe it's the same thing in this reality?
(1:33) It could have been an accident.
(2:33 - 2:40) As a mouse owner, I can tell you that mice WILL eat *a little* cheese in their diets IF it's a dry cheese. out of my 171 total mice, only a small fraction (less than 10) regularly liked it and most of them preferred dry, shredded cheeses.  There's too much fat in most cheeses for mice to eat it too much.
(9:12) Eh.  That's why there's Boxing Day.
(14:40) 1.) The "gender pay gap" is more of a result of women bitching after the fact instead of learning how to negotiate salaries (and also not knowing the difference of the values of an actor's/actress' name) 2.) If your "money muscle" is your strength, use it.  Screw those who bitch.  "They just be hatin'."
(14:52) Lagomorph, not rodent.  Hey, if you're going to be a nit-picking asshole, then so am I!

snippet.textDisplay: I literally never thought before about how Scrooge made his money via moneylending. The actual ins and outs of it. We know he's good at it. Historically, moneylenders were often popular for people who needed to build things, and had no other avenues... Even the muslims loved having jews around when they needed to do some basic banking and were forbidden from charging each other interest
snippet.textOriginal: I literally never thought before about how Scrooge made his money via moneylending. The actual ins and outs of it. We know he's good at it. Historically, moneylenders were often popular for people who needed to build things, and had no other avenues... Even the muslims loved having jews around when they needed to do some _basic banking_ and were forbidden from charging each other interest

You are right, though.  This is arguably the best Christmas movie ever made.  I put it in a three-way tie with Die Hard and Lethal Weapon.

snippet.textDisplay: Scrooge is not dumb. He knows it's him, he knows he's the guy who's death everyone's happy about, he just doesn't want to admit it. 'Cause that would make it real, and to face the truth is hard. Like really hard. Like when there's no way of denying anymore you might cry hard. You can see and hear it in his tone from the moment he heard the men/pigs talk about his death. Brilliant acting.
snippet.textOriginal: Scrooge is not dumb. He knows it's him, he knows he's the guy who's death everyone's happy about, he just doesn't want to admit it. 'Cause that would make it real, and to face the truth is hard. Like really hard. Like when there's no way of denying anymore you might cry hard. You can see and hear it in his tone from the moment he heard the men/pigs talk about his death. Brilliant acting.
